webTitle: Treasury secretary warns debt ceiling crisis is hurting US economy – as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Royal Mail and US politics liveblogs here
• Treasury secretary Lew testifies to Senate
• Lew: Prioritisation is just default
• We can't play 'parlour games' with the debt ceiling
fields.body:
4.50pm BST

Read our new blogs for more....

And with that, I'm off.

Remember you can track the US political drama here: 

Boehner eyes short-term debt ceiling fix as shutdown enters 10th day – live

and the Royal Mail privatisation action here (coming ANY MOMENT)

 Royal Mail share price and allocation announced - live

Thanks, and goodnight. GW

4.44pm BST

Here's a shocking suggestion:

As we don't celebrate Thanksgiving over here, UK tweeters & bloggers will be free...

4.41pm BST

European markets close with strong gains

European stocks markets have surged on hopes of a debt ceiling deal, even a short-term patch-up job.

The FTSE 100 index of leading shares jumped 92 points to close at 6430, a gain of almost 1.5%

The German Dax and French CAC provisionally closed 2% higher, and Spain's IBEX gained 2.2%.

In Milan the Italian FTSE MIB (which didn't join in yesterday's selloff) jumped up another 1.5% to a two-year high.

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets comments:

Having hit multi month lows earlier this week we’ve seen a much perkier session today in Europe on optimism that a meeting tonight between President Obama and senior Republicans later this evening will yield some progress as we head towards the eleventh day of the US government shutdown and the debt ceiling deadline looms ever closer.

The remainder of Europe’s markets continue to remain much more resilient to events on the other side of the Atlantic despite continued disappointing economic data. Italian markets hit their highest levels since mid-2011 even though Italian industrial production for August continued to show signs of weakness. 

And on Wall Street, the Dow Jones is up 225 points, or 1.5%, on optimism that the two sides will agree a debt ceiling extension.

4.26pm BST

There's big news coming in the UK soon -- the pricing and allocation details of the Royal Mail flotation.

Again, we have a brand new live blog to cover it, with Nick Fletcher:

Royal Mail share price and allocation announced - live

4.23pm BST

Here's another image showing how rumours of a six-week debt ceiling extension hit bonds maturing at the end of next month: 

4.19pm BST

Washington bureau chief Dan Roberts has filed a full news story on Jack Lew's warning over the looming debt ceiling. 

It begins:

The Treasury secretary, Jack Lew, warned on Thursday that the continued brinksmanship over the debt limit risks unforeseen consequences in the financial markets that could in turn lead to the US running out of cash within days.

As pressure mounted on Congress to cut a deal before next Thursday's deadline for extending the federal debt limit, Lew accused Republicans of underestimating the danger of inadvertently triggering a stampede among investors that could rapidly drain remaining reserves.

US Treasury secretary: Republicans underestimate debt ceiling danger

4.15pm BST

New Live Blog <Woot>

My US colleagues will be live-blogging all the action in Washington in the coming hours in a New Live Blog:

Boehner eyes short-term debt ceiling fix as shutdown enters 10th day – live

Tom McCarthy's in charge, and is covering all the details of the deal which House speaker John Boehner has apparently proposed.

It's being billed as a 'clean' budget deal, but it may not be clean enough 

Fox News' Ed Henry reports a version of Boehner's offer that does not sound like the "clean" debt ceiling lift the White House has insisted on. Boehner appears to be offering short-term relief on the debt ceiling in exchange for concessions to reopen the government, according to Henry.

4.06pm BST

4.05pm BST

There are now reports out of Washington that the Republicans will propose a six-week extension of the debt limit.

That would kick the can down the road to the end of November. There are already signs that nervous traders are selling short-term bonds which mature around then, pushing down their price and raising the yield.

3.59pm BST

Jack Lew testifies over debt ceiling

Here's a round-up of the key points from Treasury Secretary Jack Lew's appearance before the Senate finance committee, on the debt ceiling. (highlights start here)

• Jack Lew has warned that the 'manufactured political crisis' over the US debt ceiling and a budget for 2014 is starting to hurt the US economy, ten days after the federal government dramatically shut down.

Lew told the committee that America will probably hit its borrowing limit on 17 October, and predicted irrevocable damage if America's government were to default.

• Asked whether America was acting like a "blindfolded man walking towards a cliff", Lew replied that his big fear is that the US government should stumble into a default.

Lew also slammed politicians who imagine there's more time to haggle, saying:

In Washington there is a parlour game of 'When is the last minute'. You can't do that with the debt ceiling.

• Several Republican senators urged Lew to consider prioritising payments, to create more flexibility. Lew repeatedly dismissed the idea, saying it was politically untenable, possibly impossible in practice, and effectively a default as America would be reneging on its commitments.

• Social Security claimants would be the first to suffer if America couldn't keep borrowing, Lew said, citing the example of his own late mother who relied on hew own cheque from the government. Anyone who thinks freezing social security payments is the answer doesn't understand how the world works, he said.

• There were also a series of Republican warnings that America's real debt crisis is the size of its national debt, and its 'unaffordable entitlement commitments'.One argued that up to 80% of Americans want budget cuts agreed.

Lew, though, insists that Congress needs to get a budget agreed and the debt ceiling raised before negotiations can take place.

• Democrats pointed to growing anxiety in the markets. Democrat senator Maria Cantwell showed Lew a graph of rising bond yields, and predicted a stock market crash unless the debt ceiling is reached.

• Lew also revealed that other finance ministers express their worries to him. Overnight, China's premier had expressed his own concern to Secretary of State John Kerry.

• There was also much discussion about a short-term deal to raise the debt limit. Lew said a longer-term deal would be much better -- but any deal is better than none.

3.45pm BST

Shares are romping higher on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones up 205 points (+1.4%) now.

The FTSE 100 is also showing triple-digit gains, up 102 points or 1.6%.

Traders are calculating that there will be progress at the White House when President Obama and senior Republicans meet.

Elsewhere, the oil price has jumped $2 per barrel (Brent crude) - suggesting concern over the US economy being badly hit is easing.

3.07pm BST

Before I round-up the Jack Lew hearing -- Christine Lagarde has been discussing the debt ceiling crisis at a press conference in Washington.

Here's the early snaps:

10-Oct-2013 14:46 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS U.S. FAILURE TO RAISE DEBT CEILING WOULD CAUSE SERIOUS DAMAGE TO U.S., GLOBAL ECONOMY

10-Oct-2013 14:47 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS GETS MEMBERSHIP APPROVAL TO TRANSFER GOLD PROFITS TO LOW-INCOME COUNTRY FUND

10-Oct-2013 14:58 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS CONFIDENT U.S. FEDERAL RESERVE TAPERING WILL BE WELL-COMMUNICATED, GRADUAL TO TEMPER MARKET TURBULENCE

10-Oct-2013 15:02 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS HAS 'NO DOUBT' EUROPEAN PARTNERS WILL STICK BY COMMITMENTS MADE TO HELP GREECE 

2.54pm BST

And that really is the end -- and Jack Lew marches briskly out of the room to his next engagement.....

Updated at 2.54pm BST

2.54pm BST

Time's up. But no... the committee chair says that there are four senators who haven't spoken.

Can they have 10 seconds each? (what is it about Washington politicians and deadlines?)

Lew agrees.

The senators raise a range of concerns - including the impact on Social Security payments and the damage being caused to the jobs market.

Democrat Bill Nelson says that a short-term increase in the debt ceiling was a poor solution that threatens national security. A fourth senator, also a Democrat, also calls for a longer-term deal.

2.47pm BST

Another question, which takes us back to the start of the session. Why won't Lew engage on the issue of 'prioritisation'? America could avoid default by paying some bills and not others.

Lew takes another swipe at this idea.

No US president has ever had to decide what to pay, and what not.

It would put us into default if we could pay one bill and not others.

2.44pm BST

How much damage would there be if America's borrowing costs rose by, say, "1% or 2%"?

The cost would be billions of US dollars, Lew replies.

2.42pm BST

The Senate committee has hit its own limit -- on time. Jack Lew has to be elsewhere (the IMF annual meeting is also taking place in Washington).

Lew tries to get away, saying:

I hate to draw attention to the time…..

But the committee wants more, so Lew is going to take two more questions....

Updated at 2.45pm BST

2.41pm BST

Another discussion about whether the real debt problem is the size of America's debt, or Congress's failure to raise the limit.

Lew isn't shifting from his position that the ceiling needs to be raised, and that president Obama will negotiate on spending after Congress has met its obligations.

He's not negotiating over the debt limit…he looks forward to it being raised.

2.35pm BST

Could a short-term debt ceiling deal (ie, a small rise above the current $16.7trillion limit) give enough certainty to get the American economy moving again?

Lew repeats that he would much prefer a long-term deal, cautioning that retailers are concerned about trading in the run-up to Christmas.

As he put it:

Longer is better, but avoiding a crisis is better than having a crisis.

Remember Lew's earlier warning that the Treasury just doesn't know when it might run out of road.....

2.33pm BST

Wall Street is open, and the Dow Jones index is up 144 points, or nearly 1%, in very early trading.

2.31pm BST

Another senator explains that the debt ceiling deadlock will only be fixed when Democrats must accept reforms to entitlement spending, and Republicans must embrace tax reforms.

The president must make this crystal clear, and get the two sides together.

2.26pm BST

Republican senator Mike Enzi of Wyoming gives Lew an economics lesson.

You can't spend more than you take in, and you can't keep doing it for ever and ever and ever.

He cites a constituent who runs a firm in Wyoming. Whenever an employee asks for pay rise he explains that they have an "a problem with outflow,not income". (is there no inflation in Wyoming?!)

Enzi has had enough of the talk of 'the sky falling in'.

Lew replies that the people of Wyoming understand that they need to repay their credit card bills.

But refusing to pay obligations is not the answer.

2.21pm BST

Bob Menendez, New Jersey Democrat, says that while Barack Obama was stuck in Washington, China was cutting deals at the Asia-Pacific summit this week.

How much damage is being caused to America's role in the world economy?

Lew says it is "impossible to overstate the importance" of America's central position in the financial system, with the US dollar as the reserve currency. He says that other finance ministers ask him 'what's happening in Washington?', because they're worried about their own economies.

2.17pm BST

Republican senator Pat Roberts, of Kansas, says that 70-80% of Americans favour spending cuts being agreed alongside a new debt ceiling deal.

He criticises President Obama for insisting on a clean deal, and asks what sort of compromises the president might be amenable to when he meets with Republican leaders at the White House today.

Jack Lew replies that the president's position is clear -- Congress must reopen the government, make sure we can pay our bills, and then we can talk about anything.

2.14pm BST

Senator: Market could tumble 25%

Democrat senator Maria Cantwell produces a graph of America's short-term borrowing costs (looks like the one-month bond yield ) , showing a spike in interest rates in recent days.

She says that people don't realise the implications of America's credit-worthiness being questioned - citing an analyst in her community who predicted a 25% tumble on the stock market if a default looked likely.

Lew replies that a tripling of bond yields was not a good thing, but didn't speculate on potential market action. 

2.09pm BST

Republican senator Mike Crapo argues that America's real debt crisis is the size of the national debt. Why won't Lew and Obama agree to address its entitlement commitments?

Lew replies that the Obama administration has already halved the deficit - from 9% to 4.5%, and even gets criticism from international partners for cutting too fast.

2.05pm BST

2.03pm BST

Lew: Impossible to predict when we hit the ceiling

Democrat senator Chuck Schumer congratulates Jack Lew on his performance, and for explaining why prioritising payments was a non-starter:

The debt ceiling deniers need a dose of debt ceiling reality, and you've given them one today.

Schumer says that America is "like a blindfolded man walking towards a cliff".

We might fall off on October 16th, October 17th, October 25.... but we will fall off.

Worse of all, Schumer says, "we don't know which day we will fall off".

Lew agrees, saying that his biggest fear is that Washington suffers an unexpected event. "We're already in overtime" he adds.

Lew explains how the day-to-day fiscal management means "It is impossible to predict with accuracy" when America will actually run out of money.

In Washington there is a parlour game of 'When is the last minute?'. You can't do that with the debt ceiling.

Updated at 2.04pm BST

1.54pm BST

Lew also disputes that most recent budget deals have had a debt ceiling rise 'tied to it'.

Most budgets either didn't include a debt ceiling, or had it tacked onto the end -- rather than driving the debate.

He then takes aim at a "certain faction" which prefers the risk of default than not getting its own way, adding: 

We cannot have the debt ceiling being something that's a threat to the economy unless policy concessions are made.

1.51pm BST

How 'clean' would a debt ceiling have to be to get the Democrat's approval? 

Lew says he and Obama would need to see it, and adds that a deal that gave more freedom for future borrowing would be better.

1.50pm BST

Lew reminds the committee that US short-term borrowing costs have risen in recent days -- that raises concerns in the financial markets, and also hits the real economy.

1.49pm BST

Lew: Social Security payees in the front line

Next question: America's seniors would be in the front line if America didn't reach a deal - what would the impact be?

Lew replies that he can only begin to imagine the impact, telling the senate committee that he has personal experience of this:

My late mother lived on her social security cheque....

Anyone who thinks that this is anything short of default has never experienced what it means to live on social security.

It's not just those relying on these payments, he adds. Workers are also at risk -- but those relying on government payments would be hit first.

All the more reason to avoid a manufactured crisis, he adds.

1.45pm BST

Senator Hatch is now reminding Lew that he believes America needs to make cuts to its unsustainable entitlement spending. Why won't President Obama negotiate?

Lew replies that the president is prepared to negotiate.. "he's been on the verge of an agreement twice.. in 2011".

Obama was prepared to make some challenging decisions, Lew adds. His record on being willing to negotiate is clear.

1.42pm BST

Senator Hatch has the floor, and asks Jack Lew how much of a debt limit increase he wants, and for how long.

Lew replies:

This economy would benefit from more certainty and less brinkmanship.

but it's Congress's decision.

Hatch wants to know details.

Longer is better, Lew concludes.

1.40pm BST

Lew also warns that the disruption caused by the US government shutdown means he cannot be convinced that his old calculations for how the US finances would play out are still accurate.

1.38pm BST

First question – how could "prioritisation" of America's bills work?

Lew insists this is not a sensible idea, saying the first point is:

If we don't have enough cash to pay all our bills, we will be failing to meet our obligations.

He adds that there is no way of telling how the financial markets would view such a move -- even if it means America met its bond repayments.

Lew suggests it would be a very tough task -- saying he didn't know you'd choose social security payment, medicare and food assistance, 

We wouldn't have money to pay our troops in full, our veterans in full.

The legal authority isn't clear, and the administration system might not work, he concludes.

That's a thumbs down, folks.

Updated at 1.40pm BST

1.33pm BST

Lew also dismisses the idea that America could simply prioritise its payments

"There is no way of knowing the irrevocable damage" this would have on the markets.

This fight is the last thing our economy needs right now, he conclude.

Right, onto questions

1.31pm BST

America rolls over $100bn of debt each week, Lew says. If our lenders want the money repaid, rather than rolled over, we've got a problem.

1.31pm BST

If Congress cannot meet its obligations on the debt ceiling, it will cause damage to the US economy, the financial markets, and the "jobs and savings" of ordinary Americans, Jack Lew continues.

He also reminds the Senate committee that he's been updating Congress on this issue for months.

And he reiterates that the extraordinary measures already implemented will run out of road on the 17 October.

After that point,we don't have enough money to meet all our obligations, Lew continues, citing social security payments, medicare bills and veteran payments.

1.28pm BST

Jack Lew's now speaking, reading out his prepared statement.

Lew says that Congress must act to ensure that America's credit worthiness is not brought into question.

The biggest threat to a recovery in our economy is a manufactured political crisis. 

The uncertainty over the debt ceiling is starting to alarm the financial markets, he continues, citing a recent jump in borrowing costs.

The full faith and credit of the United States is one of our greatest assets, he continues.

(I'll post a full link to this statement shortly....) 

1.23pm BST

Republican senator Hatch also claims that the US government has misled the public by claiming that it would be unprecedented to negotiate over the debt ceiling (by making changes to the Affordable Care act).

 Hatch adds:

The issue we face is yet another debt limit increase. There have been seven since this President came to office...raising the national debt from $11.3trn to $16.7trn.

Hatch is also chiding Treasury secretary Lew for suggesting that the markets were too calm about the deadlock, in an apparent attempt to whip up alarm.

1.18pm BST

Lew's testimony underway

Jack Lew's hearing at the Senate Finance Committee is underway. 

Democrat senator Max Baucus spoke first, saying that politicians must put their differences aside today and agree an increase to the debt ceiling.

Everyone in the room has an opportunity to get America "past the brink." he added.

Republican senator Orrin Hatch is now giving a statement, reminding Lew that Barack Obama, as a humble senator, described an earlier debate over raising the debt ceiling as a sign of leadership failure. 

Updated at 1.23pm BST

1.10pm BST

Jack Lew's getting ready to testify to Senators on the looming debt ceiling.

1.08pm BST

Jack Lew's testimony released

Treasury Secretary Jack Lew's prepared testimony to the Senate finance committee just hit the wires.

Lew is reiterating that America will hit its debt ceiling on 17 October, and warning that there would be a "substantial effect" on the markets if America's credit worthiness was called into question.

Lew also warns that a "manufactured political crisis" is starting to hurt the US economy.

Cyprus's finance minister has declared that his government is aiming for a smaller budget deficit than demanded by its international lenders.

Reuters has the details:

Cyprus plans spending cuts to achieve a primary budget deficit lower than the level targeted by the bailed-out island's international lenders, its finance minister said on Thursday.

Harris Georgiades said the government aimed for a primary budget deficit - which excludes the cost of debt interest - of 3.0% of GDP, compared with 4.25% outlined in the bailout deal.

A draft budget for 2014 provides for a 10% cut in net spending compared to 2013, Georgiades told reporters.

"The basic characteristic of the budget is significant savings on expenditure. We are operating in a difficult economic environment," he said.

While Cyprus hopes for a smaller primary deficit, Greece is confident that it has posted a primary surplus so far this year. That's a key part of its deal with its own lenders.

Deputy finance minister Christos Staikouras said earlier today that Greece has managed a surplus of €2.6bn (before the cost of servicing its debts is included).

12.34pm BST

Back to the US debt ceiling deadlock.

The Hong Kong exchange's decision to hike the margin requirement on investors who use short term US debt as collateral is a "concrete step" to protect a US default, says the Wall Street Journal.

It explains that the move will force traders to put up more security, following signs of stress in the market for Treasury bills.

The WSJ also flags up that Hong Kong's regulator financial regulator is considering the implications of a US technical default:

Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission, or SFC, which helps to regulate one of the world's biggest financial hubs, is examining how defaulted U.S. treasury securities would affect their use as collateral. The watchdog's talks have included counterparts in Luxembourg and Ireland, where some Hong Kong-authorized funds are domiciled.

Securities and Futures Commission Chief Executive Ashley Alder told reporters Thursday that while the chance of a default appears unlikely, regulators need to prepare for the scenario. "If it did default, it would again expose the simple fact that the chains of intermediated risk around the financial system still exists," he said.

More here: Hong Kong Takes Concrete Action Against U.S. Default 

12.15pm BST

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), agrees that the Bank of England made the right call, but suggests the quantitative easing programme could be tweaked to help small firms:

There is no case for increasing QE at present. Despite the disappointing manufacturing and trade figures this week, the economy is recovering, and adding to QE could risk increasing inflation.

While the Bank of England’s balance sheet is sufficiently large, there are strong arguments in favour of changing its composition by replacing some of the gilts with private sector assets such as securitised SME loans. This will make such assets less risky and make it easier for the Bank to increase lending.

12.15pm BST

Bank of England sits on hands - early reaction

The news that the Bank of England has left interest rates and its bond-buying programme (QE) unchanged was greeted with a resounding shrug by the City (although with Mark Carney at the helm, a statement couldn't be ruled out).

Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight called it a "stone dead certainty", but warned that "a nasty accident on the US debt front" could easily shake the Bank into action.

He writes:

The bar for any more QE now looks to be very high. It will likely only occur if the economy loses substantial momentum over the coming months, or if there is major financial turmoil and a sharp upward move in market interest rates when the US Federal Reserve finally starts to taper. Our central scenario is that neither of these events will happen, but neither can be ruled out.

Of course if the US defaults on its debt, we could be in a whole different ball game given the likely global economic and financial market turmoil this would cause.

In the foreign exchange markets, the pound is pretty flat against the US dollar at $1.5948, and down just 0.1% against the euro at €1.1784.

Updated at 12.15pm BST

12.00pm BST

Bank of England rate decision

The Bank of England has left UK interest rates, and its stimulus package, unchanged.

The Bank's Monetary Policy Committee voted to leave headline borrowing costs unchanged at 0.5%, and made no changes to its quantitative easing programme.

That means it will still hold £375bn of UK government debt.

No sign of a statement from the BoE either.....

11.55am BST

Dutch government struggles to agree austerity budget

A political flap is brewing in the Netherlands today as the government tries to agree a deal over an austerity budget for 2014.

Finance minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem (who also chairs the eurogroup) cancelled his trip to Washington for the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting. Instead, he will to focus on reaching an agreement on €6bn of cutbacks for next year.

That budget is in the balance after a second opposition party, the Greens, refused to support the measures last night. 

Dijsselbloem told national broadcaster NOS today:

I will not be going to Washington, as the budget talks have more priority," he told national broadcaster NOS.

Dijsselbloem's absence is a little awkward, as he was due to represent the eurozone countries at the IMF's gathering.

But domestic problems demand his attention, as the Dutch government tries to impose the €6bn of cuts to get its deficit within 3% of GDP.

As Dijsselbloem's spokesman Michel Reijns put it:

He regrets the decision, but at the moment he had to give priority to domestic matters

It is an attempt to find support for the budget measures.

Dijsselbloem spend five hours yesterday talking to opposition leaders, going beyond midnight in an attempt to get a deal. Two parties have already quit the discussions, leaving three - who between them could give the government the votes it needs.

11.38am BST

Quick reminder that the Bank of England announces its monetary policy decision at noon BST -- economists don't expect any drama though.

The excitement could come at 1.30pm BST, when treasury secretary Jack Lew starts testifying on the debt ceiling to the Senate Finance Committee.

11.16am BST

Shares rally on hopes of US breakthrough

European stock markets have posted some pretty decent gains today, driven by the overnight reports that a short-term deal to raise the US debt ceiling could be agreed.

The main indices are up over 1% each (clawing back some, but not all, of the recent losses). In London the FTSE 100 is up 63 points.

We're still expecting Barack Obama to meet with senior Republicans at the White House later today (Marketwatch has more details).

Traders suspect that the dime may have fallen on Capitol Hill that they can't risk a technical default. The analyst team at Monex Capital Markets sums it up:

Lawmakers in Washington do seem now to be accepting just how big the fall-out would be for both the US and the global economy in the event of the debt ceiling being breached.

As such there have been murmurings that a short term increase in the borrowing limit may be on the table, although with a week to run until doomsday, there will doubtless be further political grandstanding to be seen.

10.51am BST

Hong Kong is firing a 'warning shot' to Washington to sort out the debt ceiling crisis quickly, by hiking the haircut demanded when traders use US debt as collateral, says Brenda Kelly of IG.

She writes:

Reassurances from the US that short-term measures will be instigated to avert the upcoming debt-ceiling deadline have given European equity markets a jolt upwards, helping to stem some of the risk aversion of the past few days.

News that Hong Kong has raised collateral haircuts on US treasury bills appears to be something of a warning shot to US politicians. The implications are that US treasury bonds are considered broadly more risky and the Hong Kong exchange is clearly preparing for the worst case scenario – a US default. The more likely explanation is that Hong Kong is simply telling the US to get its act together.

If so, it's the warning shot heard on trading floors around the world.... 

Updated at 10.52am BST

10.33am BST

Greek unemployment data released

Greece's unemployment rate hit 27.6% in July, new data shows, in a stark example of the despair and joblessness which the  International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies is warning about today.

That's an increase on June's 27.5% -- revised down from a first estimate of 27.9%. 

ESTAT reports that there were 3,610,549 people employed in July, and 1,374,054 classed as unemployed. A further 3,375,636 people were 'inactive".

A quarter of men are unemployed, compared to 31% of women. 

And you already know that the youth jobless rate was awful - for the record, 55.1% of 15-24 year olds were classed as unemployed.

The data is seasonally adjusted, and the Hellenic Statistical Authority says it can see signs that the jobless rate may have stopped rising. It said:

During the last 3 months we observe a stabilization of the estimated seasonally adjusted unemployment rate.

Confirmation from Markit that the cost of insuring US 5-year debt against default has fallen, and insuring 1-year debt hasn't risen...

The cost of protection against the US government defaulting on a 12-month bond is unchanged this morning, while the cost of insuring five-year Treasuries has actually dropped a little:

10.10am BST

9.54am BST

Hong Kong hikes haircut on US debt

Back to America's growing debt ceiling crisis, and the news that Hong Kong securities and future's exchange is treating US short-term bonds as riskier.

The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEx) is raising the "haircut" which traders pay when they use short-term Treasury Bills as collateral, (the Financial Times is reporting).

Here's the HKEx statement:

This new haircut shall be applied on a daily basis to determine the value of the US Treasuries [sic] allowed to be used as cover for the margin requirements of HKCC [Hong Kong Clearing Corporation] participants.

Participants should make necessary funding arrangements to cover any shortfall to their margin requirements resulting from the increase in the US Treasuries haircut.

That means they're being treated as less safe -- reflecting the risk that America might stumble into a technical default unless the debt ceiling is raised soon. 

Here's the FT story: HK exchange prepares for US bond default

This comes just hours after the Chinese premier told John Kerry about his concerns over the debt ceiling deadlock (see opening post). Is Beijing sending a signal to Washington to get a grip?

Updated at 10.08am BST

9.41am BST

Ian Traynor also filed a devastating piece on the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies's report into the damage caused by European austerity.

When speaking privately, Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, is fond of wrinkling her nose and indicating her distaste for a word that does not really exist in her own language – austerity.

It is a word that has dominated her years at the helm of the eurozone crisis. She has heard it a lot. She does not like it. But the spending cuts, "structural reforms", slashed budgets, decimated public services and wrenching social and cultural upheavals imposed on Europe's fringes over the past four years to save the euro are a result of the austerity that has been the "made in Germany" policy response to the troubles.

Merkel and her fellow leaders in northern Europe and in Brussels are already mildly sanguine that they have weathered the worst of the euro-storm. The markets are calm.

The banks, whose irresponsible lending spree did much to produce the crisis in the first place, are raking in squillions, the bulk of the hundreds of billions in bailout funds lent by the eurozone since 2010. Crisis over? Not in the real economy, where it may just really be beginning.

Here's the full piece:

Crisis over in the eurozone? Not in the real world 

9.32am BST

Red Cross sounds alarm on European austerity

A major report published today is warning that the austerity measures imposed in Europe since the debt crisis began are creating a deep social and economic decline.

In a detailed survey, the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies warns that tens of millions of Europeans face years of gloom and despair, painting a picture of growing poverty, mass unemployment, and social exclusion.

The full scale of the crisis is not yet clear, it warns.

In a critique which should send shivers through Brussels and the corridors of European power, the report states bleakly that:

Whilst other continents successfully reduce poverty, Europe adds to it.

European editor Ian Traynor reports:

The damning critique, obtained exclusively by the Guardian, of the policy response to the debt crisis that surfaced in Greece in late 2009 and raised fundamental questions about the viability of the euro single currency, foresees extremely gloomy prospects for tens of millions of Europeans.

Mass unemployment – especially among the young, 120 million Europeans living in or at risk of poverty – increased waves of illegal immigration clashing with rising xenophobia in the host countries, growing risks of social unrest and political instability estimated to be two to three times higher than most other parts of the world, greater levels of insecurity among the traditional middle classes – all combine to make a European future more uncertain than at any time in the postwar era.

"As the economic crisis has planted its roots, millions of Europeans live with insecurity, uncertain about what the future holds. This is one of the worst psychological states of mind for human beings. We see quiet desperation spreading among Europeans, resulting in depression, resignation and loss of hope. Compared to 2009, millions more find themselves queuing for food, unable to buy medicine nor access healthcare. Millions are without a job and many of those who still have work face difficulties to sustain their families due to insufficient wages and skyrocketing prices. 

Austerity pushing Europe into social and economic decline, says Red Cross

9.08am BST

And here's our full story: SSE raises prices by 8.2% – adding £104 to average bill

9.01am BST

Labour blames Cameron for SSE price rise

Labour was quick to use SSE's energy price rise as proof that bill should be frozen.

Caroline Flint MP, Shadow Energy and Climate Change Secretary, also said:

Hard-pressed consumers are now paying the price for David Cameron's failure to stand up to the energy companies.

When times are tough energy companies should be helping their customers not hitting them with more price rises to boost their profits. That's why a Labour Government would freeze energy prices and reset Britain's energy market to stop people being ripped off.

Energy price rises were a big issue at Prime Minister's Questions yesterday. Cameron claimed the Labour price freeze is a 'gimmick' and that it supports Green initiatives that would push prices even higher, while Miliband said the PM had no answer on the issue: 

Ed Miliband turns up heat on David Cameron over energy bills

Updated at 9.06am BST

8.49am BST

In the UK, energy prices have come roaring back up the political agenda after SSE became the first supplier to hike prices.

SSE announced the 8.2% tariff increase this morning, which will slap another £100 or so on the average annual dual-fuel bill. The move comes just a fortnight after Labour leader Ed Miliband promised a price freeze if he wins the next election.

SSE said it was "sorry", and tried to pin the blame on wholesale price increase and government tariffs.

There's a long explanation here, in which Will Morris, SSE's retail group managing director, said:

We're sorry we have to do this. We've done as much as we could to keep prices down, but the reality is that buying wholesale energy in global markets, delivering it to customers' homes, and government-imposed levies collected through bills - endorsed by all the major parties - all cost more than they did last year.

Eighty five per cent of a typical energy bill is made up of costs outside our direct control and these costs have increased. So far this year we have made a loss from supplying energy as a result of the higher costs we have been facing and continue to face.

No-one wants to be seen as the energy company's friend right now. Business minister Michael Fallon took to Sky News to encourage SSE customers to "consider switching to a cheaper tariff":

Updated at 9.06am BST

8.40am BST

European stock markets are up in early trading, on hopes that America's politicians may bow to the growing pressure and agree some sort of deal. If only a temporary one.

Last night, a Republican aide hinted that the party might be amenable to a short-term increase in the government's borrowing authority, and discussing broader policy measures over a longer timeframe.

That idea could move forward tonight, when Barack Obama meets Republican leaders at the White House.

8.26am BST

Philippines taking 'defensive position' over US debt

China isn't the only country worried that America is about to trigger a global panic by not raising its debt ceiling.

The looming deadline has cast a shadow over a summit of Southeast Asian nations in Brunei. President Obama was meant to be there too – but remained in Washington to try to drive a budget deal, and debt ceiling increase, through Congress.

The Financial Times flags up that the Philippines says it's now taking a “defensive position” to protect itself in the case of a US debt default.

“The Philippines government is aware of the possibility; we’re taking steps to protect our position and ensure that the effects of this will be as little as possible,” said a spokesman for Benigno Aquino, the country’s president.

“But this is something that’s never happened before and so we don’t know how it’s going to affect the entire world and what it can do to us.”

He refused to elaborate, saying he that did not want to “create more nervousness about the situation”.

Last night it emerged that Fidelity, America's largest money market mutual fund manager, had sold all its Short-Term U.S. Government Debt which matured in late October or early November - just in case there was a default.

Bond trading giant Pimco, though, says it's buying Treasury bills....

7.57am BST

China expresses concerns over debt ceiling deadlock

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. 

It's the tenth day of the US government shutdown, and patience with Washington's inability to either pass a budget or agree to raise its debt ceiling before the 17 October deadline is running out.

Overnight, China has gone public again with its concerns. Chinese premier Li Keqiang warned Secretary of State John Kerry that Beijing is worried about the U.S. debt-ceiling issue .

A brief statement in English on State-run China News Service reported that Li expressed

Beijing's concern about Washington' s debt-ceiling problem.

The comments come as BAE Systems, the defence contractor, fired a warning shot at America this morning, warning shareholders that the ongoing uncertainty had already forced it to send over a thousand workers home.

In a statement to the City, BAE explains that it's already feeling the impact of the partial US government shutdown.

Whilst the impact of this action has not yet been material to the Group's overall financial performance, some progressive impact to the Group's US operations would result from a protracted government shutdown.

Since the 1 October shutdown, approximately 1,200 employees across the Intelligence & Security and Support Solutions businesses have been temporarily directed not to report to work.

BAE's warning comes amid signs of optimism that politicians on Capitol Hill might hammer out a deal before America crashes into its debt ceiling, potentially derailing the world economy. That's expected to push shares high in Europe today.

CMC's Market's Michael Hewson reports:

Even allowing for this slightly positive finish concerns about the ongoing deadlock on Capitol Hill remain close to hand, though there does appear to be some optimism that discussions are still ongoing with the President due to meet 20 senior Republicans this evening in an attempt to break the deadlock.

There has been some talk of a short term debt cap bill with neither side ruling this option out in order to buy more time to come to a more permanent agreement.

Lots more afoot today, including Treasury Secretary Jack Lew testifying at the Senate on the debt ceiling deadlock, and the Bank of England's interest rate decision at noon.....

Here's a round-up of the key points from Treasury Secretary Jack Lew's appearance before the Senate finance committee, on the debt ceiling. (highlights start here) • Jack Lew has warned that the 'manufactured political crisis' over the US debt ceiling and a budget for 2014 is starting to hurt the US economy, ten days after the federal government dramatically shut down. Lew told the committee that America will probably hit its borrowing limit on 17 October, and predicted irrevocable damage if America's government were to default. • Asked whether America was acting like a "blindfolded man walking towards a cliff", Lew replied that his big fear is that the US government should stumble into a default. Lew also slammed politicians who imagine there's more time to haggle, saying: In Washington there is a parlour game of 'When is the last minute'. You can't do that with the debt ceiling. • Several Republican senators urged Lew to consider prioritising payments, to create more flexibility. Lew repeatedly dismissed the idea, saying it was politically untenable, possibly impossible in practice, and effectively a default as America would be reneging on its commitments. • Social Security claimants would be the first to suffer if America couldn't keep borrowing, Lew said, citing the example of his own late mother who relied on hew own cheque from the government. Anyone who thinks freezing social security payments is the answer doesn't understand how the world works, he said. • There were also a series of Republican warnings that America's real debt crisis is the size of its national debt, and its 'unaffordable entitlement commitments'.One argued that up to 80% of Americans want budget cuts agreed. Lew, though, insists that Congress needs to get a budget agreed and the debt ceiling raised before negotiations can take place. • Democrats pointed to growing anxiety in the markets. Democrat senator Maria Cantwell showed Lew a graph of rising bond yields, and predicted a stock market crash unless the debt ceiling is reached. • Lew also revealed that other finance ministers express their worries to him. Overnight, China's premier had expressed his own concern to Secretary of State John Kerry. • There was also much discussion about a short-term deal to raise the debt limit. Lew said a longer-term deal would be much better -- but any deal is better than none. Shares are romping higher on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones up 205 points (+1.4%) now. Before I round-up the Jack Lew hearing -- Christine Lagarde has been discussing the debt ceiling crisis at a press conference in Washington. Here's the early snaps: 10-Oct-2013 14:46 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS U.S. FAILURE TO RAISE DEBT CEILING WOULD CAUSE SERIOUS DAMAGE TO U.S., GLOBAL ECONOMY 10-Oct-2013 14:47 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS GETS MEMBERSHIP APPROVAL TO TRANSFER GOLD PROFITS TO LOW-INCOME COUNTRY FUND 10-Oct-2013 14:58 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS CONFIDENT U.S. FEDERAL RESERVE TAPERING WILL BE WELL-COMMUNICATED, GRADUAL TO TEMPER MARKET TURBULENCE 10-Oct-2013 15:02 - IMF'S LAGARDE SAYS HAS 'NO DOUBT' EUROPEAN PARTNERS WILL STICK BY COMMITMENTS MADE TO HELP GREECE And that really is the end -- and Jack Lew marches briskly out of the room to his next engagement..... Time's up. But no... the committee chair says that there are four senators who haven't spoken. Can they have 10 seconds each? (what is it about Washington politicians and deadlines?) Lew agrees. The senators raise a range of concerns - including the impact on Social Security payments and the damage being caused to the jobs market. Democrat Bill Nelson says that a short-term increase in the debt ceiling was a poor solution that threatens national security. A fourth senator, also a Democrat, also calls for a longer-term deal. Another question, which takes us back to the start of the session. Why won't Lew engage on the issue of 'prioritisation'? America could avoid default by paying some bills and not others. Lew takes another swipe at this idea. No US president has ever had to decide what to pay, and what not. It would put us into default if we could pay one bill and not others. How much damage would there be if America's borrowing costs rose by, say, "1% or 2%"? The cost would be billions of US dollars, Lew replies. The Senate committee has hit its own limit -- on time. Jack Lew has to be elsewhere (the IMF annual meeting is also taking place in Washington). Lew tries to get away, saying: I hate to draw attention to the time….. But the committee wants more, so Lew is going to take two more questions.... Another discussion about whether the real debt problem is the size of America's debt, or Congress's failure to raise the limit. Lew isn't shifting from his position that the ceiling needs to be raised, and that president Obama will negotiate on spending after Congress has met its obligations. He's not negotiating over the debt limit…he looks forward to it being raised. Could a short-term debt ceiling deal (ie, a small rise above the current $16.7trillion limit) give enough certainty to get the American economy moving again? Lew repeats that he would much prefer a long-term deal, cautioning that retailers are concerned about trading in the run-up to Christmas. As he put it: Longer is better, but avoiding a crisis is better than having a crisis. Remember Lew's earlier warning that the Treasury just doesn't know when it might run out of road..... Wall Street is open, and the Dow Jones index is up 144 points, or nearly 1%, in very early trading. Another senator explains that the debt ceiling deadlock will only be fixed when Democrats must accept reforms to entitlement spending, and Republicans must embrace tax reforms. The president must make this crystal clear, and get the two sides together. Republican senator Mike Enzi of Wyoming gives Lew an economics lesson. You can't spend more than you take in, and you can't keep doing it for ever and ever and ever. He cites a constituent who runs a firm in Wyoming. Whenever an employee asks for pay rise he explains that they have an "a problem with outflow,not income". (is there no inflation in Wyoming?!) Enzi has had enough of the talk of 'the sky falling in'. Lew replies that the people of Wyoming understand that they need to repay their credit card bills. But refusing to pay obligations is not the answer. Bob Menendez, New Jersey Democrat, says that while Barack Obama was stuck in Washington, China was cutting deals at the Asia-Pacific summit this week. How much damage is being caused to America's role in the world economy? Lew says it is "impossible to overstate the importance" of America's central position in the financial system, with the US dollar as the reserve currency. He says that other finance ministers ask him 'what's happening in Washington?', because they're worried about their own economies. Republican senator Pat Roberts, of Kansas, says that 70-80% of Americans favour spending cuts being agreed alongside a new debt ceiling deal. He criticises President Obama for insisting on a clean deal, and asks what sort of compromises the president might be amenable to when he meets with Republican leaders at the White House today. Jack Lew replies that the president's position is clear -- Congress must reopen the government, make sure we can pay our bills, and then we can talk about anything. Democrat senator Maria Cantwell produces a graph of America's short-term borrowing costs (looks like the one-month bond yield ) , showing a spike in interest rates in recent days. She says that people don't realise the implications of America's credit-worthiness being questioned - citing an analyst in her community who predicted a 25% tumble on the stock market if a default looked likely. Lew replies that a tripling of bond yields was not a good thing, but didn't speculate on potential market action. Republican senator Mike Crapo argues that America's real debt crisis is the size of the national debt. Why won't Lew and Obama agree to address its entitlement commitments? Lew replies that the Obama administration has already halved the deficit - from 9% to 4.5%, and even gets criticism from international partners for cutting too fast. Democrat senator Chuck Schumer congratulates Jack Lew on his performance, and for explaining why prioritising payments was a non-starter: The debt ceiling deniers need a dose of debt ceiling reality, and you've given them one today. Schumer says that America is "like a blindfolded man walking towards a cliff". We might fall off on October 16th, October 17th, October 25.... but we will fall off. Worse of all, Schumer says, "we don't know which day we will fall off". Lew agrees, saying that his biggest fear is that Washington suffers an unexpected event. "We're already in overtime" he adds. Lew explains how the day-to-day fiscal management means "It is impossible to predict with accuracy" when America will actually run out of money. In Washington there is a parlour game of 'When is the last minute?'. You can't do that with the debt ceiling. webTitle: US Treasury secretary: Republicans underestimate debt ceiling danger

fields.standfirst: Jack Lew issues fresh warning to Congress that political tussle could cause the US to run out of cash if deadline passes
fields.body:
The Treasury secretary, Jack Lew, warned on Thursday that the continued brinksmanship over the debt limit risks unforeseen consequences in the financial markets that could in turn lead to the US running out of cash within days.

As pressure mounted on Congress to cut a deal before next Thursday's deadline for extending the federal debt limit, Lew accused Republicans of underestimating the danger of inadvertently triggering a stampede among investors that could rapidly drain remaining reserves.

More than $100bn of the US debt, known as Treasury bonds, is typically reissued every week as investors roll over their loans to the government. Typically this process is routine and does not add to the $17tn US debt pile, but simply refinances a portion of it.

But markets have already been spooked by Republican threats to refuse to extend the debt limit if they do not extract concessions on healthcare reform. Short-term borrowing costs nearly tripled in a bond auction on Tuesday as investors feared there was a risk that interest and capital repayments could be missed.

A similar wariness to roll over bonds expiring next week could exhaust a $50bn cash reserve at any point, warned Lew. "Trying to time a debt limit increase to the last minute could be very dangerous," he said in written congressional testimony. "If US bond holders decided that they wanted to be repaid rather than continuing to roll over their Treasury investments, we could unexpectedly dissipate our entire cash balance."

Answering written questions by members of the Senate finance committee, he added: "I very much fear that miscalculation is something that could have devastating consequences. It is impossible to predict with any degree of accuracy when we will run out of money."

Lew's warnings came as House Republicans showed signs of bowing to pressure from donors and business supporters to back down from their threat to withhold a debt limit authorisation unless the White House agreed to first discuss spending reductions.

Republican aides said on Thursday that House speaker John Boehner will ask House Republicans to approve a short-term extension of the government's ability to borrow to meet its bills.

Boehner is due to meet Obama for fresh talks on Thursday afternoon and is expected to urge his conservative colleagues to act before the government runs out of borrowing authority next week.

Republicans have been insistent that budget cuts and other measures be added to the so-called debt ceiling legislation but the aides wouldn't say whether he'll seek to add other material to the measure.

The aides required anonymity to reveal the information before Boehner makes an announcement after a closed-door meeting with his GOP colleagues.

Lew warned that if they failed to reach a deal it would be impossible to "prioritise" certain bills due next – as some Republicans have urged – because computer systems made it impossible to selectively refuse some spending obligations but not others.

"Between October 17 and November 1, we have large payments to Medicare providers, social security beneficiaries, and veterans, as well as salaries for active duty members of the military," he said. "A failure to raise the debt limit could put timely payment of all of these at risk."

Some Republicans on the committee accused Lew of exaggerating the risks of debt limit breach compared the broader problems of excessive debt.

But Democratic committee member Ron Wyden said the repercussions of default were hard to overstate. "In the event of a default or near default, the dominoes are going to fall fast and hard."

The Associated Press contributed to this report

webTitle: Mobile networks face fivefold increase in cost of renting spectrum

fields.standfirst: Ofcom recommends rise in annual licence fees from £64.4m to £309m amid fears that customers will be hit
fields.body:
Mobile networks are facing a fivefold increase in the cost of renting spectrum from the government, amid warnings that the price hikes will be passed on to customers and hamper investment in 4G.

Annual licence fees will be ramped to £309m a year, up from the current annual total of £64.4m, under proposals published on Thursday by the telecoms regulator Ofcom. The fees apply to spectrum that was given away by the government in the early years of the mobile phone industry, before the 3G auction attracted bids worth billions.

The government wants a price hike from next year, to reflect the value of a scarce resource that has become essential in the age of the smartphone, but there are concerns that customers could pay a high price for the Treasury's windfall.

webTitle: Royal Mail privatisation: government to announce share price and allocation

fields.standfirst:
Allocation and share price due after 4.30pm after emergency meeting to work out how to deal with phenomenal demand

Royal Mail share price announcement - live updates
fields.body:
The government will announce the final details of how it will divide Royal Mail shares between the public and the City investors shortly after 4.30pm today.

Ministers held an emergency meeting earlier on Thursday to work out how to deal with phenomenal demand for shares in the privatisation.

More than 700,000 people have applied for the shares , reviving the privatisation fever last seen in the 1980s.

Vince Cable, the business secretary, said the public had placed orders for more than seven times the number of shares available to them. Small investors could have bought the entire company if the 70% of the shares on sale had not been reserved for City investors and pension funds. The government may decide to increase the proportion of shares available to the public at the expense of financial institutions.

The huge demand means that applications are bound to be scaled back. Those applying for the minimum £750 of shares may be the only ones to get what they have applied for while those who applied for shares worth thousands are expected to get just a fraction of what they wanted.

The BBC's business editor, Robert Peston, suggested that those who applied for more than £10,000 – the maximum allowed via orders direct from the government – may not collect any shares at all.

Michael Fallon, the business minister in charge of the sale, has said he is committed to making sure small investors "get their fair share" of Royal Mail shares. The Guardian has previously reported that the government will increase the proportion available to the public.

On top of the massive public demand, hedge funds and other institutional investors are understood to have placed orders for more than £30bn of the shares.

Cable said institutional demand was so strong that the government would be able to block shares from going to "spivs and speculators" in favour of "responsible long-term institutional investors".

The shares will almost certainly be priced at 330p, valuing the 500-year-old company at £3.3bn. The valuation has been attacked by the Labour party, which claims the government has massively undervalued the company and is shortchanging taxpayers.

Traders at IG Index expected Royal Mail's shares to spike to between 395p and 415p on Friday when the company is floated on the stock exchange. A rise to 400p would be a near-instant 21% paper return.

A City analyst on Thursday said Royal Mail could be worth as much as £6bn, almost double the government's maximum valuation.

The valuation by stockbroker Canaccord Genuity was the second to say the government had seriously undervalued Royal Mail, potentially shortchanging taxpayers by more than £1bn. It came as ministers held an emergency meeting to decide how to share out Royal Mail's shares following overwhelming demand from the public, City investors and pension funds. It is understood David Cameron will make a final decision on Thursday afternoon.

Canaccord said it believed the government could have sold Royal Mail shares at 599p, 269p more than the shares will be sold at when the company floats on the stock market on Friday morning.

Canaccord told its clients that its valuation "implies an 82% upside" on the 330p the government is expected to sell shares for. If Canaccord is correct in its valuation – which is based on the cashflow model Quest, which was developed by City expert Terry Smith – it means the government may have missed out on the extra £1.6bn it could have raised for taxpayers if it had sold the shares at 600p.

The Canaccord valuation came after rival stockbroker Panmure Gordon said the government had undervalued Royal Mail by "more than £1bn". Gert Zonneveld, Panmure's managing director, said the government should have valued the company at up to £4.5bn.

Panmure and Canaccord are the only two brokers to have published research as most of the others are involved in the sale and prevented from talking about the valuation.

Cable said he was confident the shares had been "priced in the right place". He said that Panmure Gordon's £4.5bn valuation was "way outside the estimates of most of the equity analysts".

Lord Forsyth, a former Tory cabinet minister, told the BBC's Daily Politics on Thursday that "clearly the pricing has been wrong".

In a note titled "A royal return on your money", Canaccord said: "We think there will be lots of happy shareholders with a minimum subscription come the 11th of October, but how many of them will be in it for the long-term? With unions being bought off and the UK economy recovering, and given the massive upside, the smart money will do well to hoover them up."

Canaccord said Royal Mail could be worth as much as £10bn by 2015 if the company was able to cut 3% of its 150,000 workforce and increase sales by 3%.

"But, the real interest is what if the company could reduce people costs? The operating gearing is massive," it said in the note.

Royal Mail has warned that it will cut an unspecified number of jobs in the next few years. It has already axed 50,000 jobs over the past decade.

webTitle: Ofgem to consult on energy profits transparency

fields.standfirst: Regulator says it recognises consumers' concerns over profit levels, after critical report from select committee
fields.body:
The energy regulator, Ofgem, has succumbed to public anger over energy prices and will launch a consultation on how to build greater transparency into energy company profits.

The regulator made the announcement in response to a sharply critical report from the energy select committee. Disputes over the true profitability of the big six energy firms has been at the heart of the debate sparked by Ed Miliband's call for a 20-month freeze on energy prices after 2015.

Ofgem said: "We recognise consumers remain concerned as to whether current profit levels are justified and we acknowledge the committee's views on the need for further action. We therefore propose to consult how best to build confidence in the market through greater transparency around profits.

"This will include but not be limited to potential improvements to the information made publicly available about energy company profitability by Ofgem and the companies themselves. We will set out in full the reasoning behind our existing measures and will explore whether new evidence has emerged since their implementation that would now justify a different approach."

Ofgem has defended itself from claims that it allows energy companies to mask their profitability, pointing out that it requires firms to break down their profits by segments including wholesale and generation.

The Department of Energy said Ofgem would explore the extent to which rate of return on capital could usefully contribute to assessing profits. There is likely to be a new annual competition assessment to judge the extent to which new players can enter the market.

The department says energy prices will continue to rise but denies this is due to excessive regulatory burdens being imposed on energy firms to meet green targets.

It said: "The wholesale cost of fuel makes up around 50% of the average dual-fuel bill and has been the largest contributing factor to increases in bills in recent years, accounting for at least 60% of the increase in household energy bills between 2010 and 2012. The remainder of the average dual fuel bill is made up of: transmission, distribution and metering costs which account for 20%, other supplier costs and margins which account for 19%, and VAT which accounts for 5%.

"Government policies to achieve energy savings, provide support to vulnerable consumers through the warm home discount scheme and incentivise the shift from fossil fuels to alternatives are estimated to account for around 9% of household energy bills. Accounting for efficiency savings, household energy bills in 2013 are expected to be 5% lower on average than they would have been if these policies were never introduced."

webTitle: SSE energy price rise 'a bitter pill for customers'

fields.standfirst: Dismay marks reaction of consumer groups to the news of the first of the big six energy companies to raise prices this winter
fields.body:
Energy company SSE has announced plans to increase prices by 8.2% from 15 November, adding around £104 to average annual household bills.

As the debate over energy prices intensifies, here is some of the reaction to the news.

Gillian Guy, chief executive of Citizens Advice, has pleaded with other energy companies to refrain from following SSE's lead or risk pushing more people into poverty.

"This price rise will be a blow for stretched budgets. The hike comes at a time when some working households are turning to food banks to feed their families as they struggle to cope with the rising cost of living. I hope other energy firms show an understanding of their customers' financial situation by not raising their prices this winter.

"Many households are facing a daily battle try to make their frozen incomes cover mounting energy, food and travel costs. Further increases will push people into poverty."

However Mark Todd, director at price comparison service energyhelpline, warned that other price hikes would follow.

"The dam has burst, expect a flood of price rises to follow. Other major suppliers are very likely to follow suit in a matter of days. It will be a bitter pill to swallow for customers who have been hit by 40% price rises now in the last 4 years. Price rise, price rise, price rise, price rise and no respite.

"The price hike will mean cash-strapped households will see their wallets stretched even further each month. Now, SSE is the most expensive by a mile."

Which? executive director Richard Lloyd said the government needed to do more.

"Current plans to reform the energy market simply don't go far enough. We want the government to intervene to make sure everything possible is done to keep prices in check.

"We need simpler pricing, we need to break the stranglehold of the biggest energy companies by separating domestic supply from generation and the government must make sure that its own policies are not adding unnecessary costs to consumers' bills."

Friends of the Earth energy campaigner Donna Hume said: "On the very day the weather turns cold, cash-strapped households are bracing themselves for massive hikes in their energy bills, driven by the nation's dependency on increasingly expensive gas.

"The big six have been reaping bumper profits by keeping the nation hooked on costly fossil fuels for far too long – it's time to fix our broken energy system.

"Ministers must take action by adding a clear clean-power target to its energy bill to encourage investors to develop the UK's huge renewable potential, create thousands of jobs and build an energy system we can all afford."

Jeremy Cryer, energy spokesman at price comparison website Gocompare.com, said customers who want more control over what they spend on energy should consider switching to a fixed deal.

"SSE's announcement has kicked off the inevitable domino effect of energy price rises that we have come to expect at this time of year. It's now just a case of when, rather than if, the rest of the big six will follow suit.

"If you're concerned about the rising cost of gas and electricity and would like to have some control over how much you spend for a longer period, consider switching to a fixed deal."

Joe Malinowski, founder of energy price comparison website TheEnergyShop.com pointed out that while SSE was the first of the big six to raise prices, smaller supplier Ebico had also announced a 9.8% hike from 15 November.

"This will take the average Ebico dual fuel bill from an eye-watering £1,376 a year to an absolutely jaw-dropping £1,511. An annual increase of £135, over £10 more each month.

"If energy suppliers needed an excuse to push up prices, then they just got it. Ebico's move will provide the perfect excuse that the big six needed. Expect a wave of price increases to kick in from now and continue throughout the winter.

"Whether energy prices rise sooner or later no longer matters. It is not worth taking the risk of waiting. There are still some great fixed energy deals out there but they will not last long. You really need to get them while you still can."

Ian McCaig, chief executive of smaller energy supplier First Utility, said it would freeze prices until after winter.

"While it's true that the costs of providing energy are increasing, we took a decision to fix our prices until after the winter to help protect families from feeling the brunt of energy cost increases during the coldest months.

"First Utility is genuinely focused on reducing energy costs for consumers and our price promise, alongside some of the cheapest long-term fixed deals on the market, demonstrate there are other options available for consumers."

webTitle: GDP growth? Public sector cuts explain why business failed to invest

fields.standfirst: The OBR's reasons for lack of GDP growth originated from a government policy leaving business leaders without a life raft
fields.body:
The government's independent economic forecaster says optimistic predictions for GDP growth it made in 2010 were off target because businesses failed to invest as expected.

In a look back at its record since the last election, the Office for Budget Responsibility wants to set the record straight. It says public sector cuts hurt the economy and exaggerated the recession, but no more than expected (Jonathan Portes at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research discusses this in his latest blog). The unexpected came from a different quarter. It was the private sector's refusal to put its profits to work by buying new equipment and processes.

In 2010 the OBR boldly claimed a business investment boom was imminent as firms looked to capitalise on the shake-out from the recession. Opportunities from a rise in export orders and increased consumer demand would drive the investment cycle into an upswing, went the story. Once in train, business investment would drive GDP back above its previous peak and end the depression.

It didn't happen. UK GDP is still 2.7% below its peak. That a lack of business investment wrecked the OBR's forecasts is obvious. That it undermined GDP growth is also pretty obvious.

The grittier problem, one that needs more digging and sifting, relates to why business investment has sagged and, according to the latest data, is still falling.

The OBR blames the eurozone crisis and the inflation spikes borne of commodity price shocks. In addition, lower than expected corporate profits and uncertainty about government policy played a part. According to this view, businesses were paralysed by a bleak world economic outlook.

But there is another view:

1. What we know about investment is that it is mostly carried out by larger companies and their profits bounced back quickly from 2011. For some time now they have sat on a cash mountain.

2. Commodity inflation is a problem, but has been offset by low wages, which have kept input costs in check.

3. The eurozone crisis was difficult, but effectively ended in July 2012 when the European Central Bank said it would underwrite every country to save the euro.

4. The OBR mentions that uncertainty over government policy was a factor. Surely this underplays the conservative risk/reward debate that goes on in every boardroom.

It underplays the effect on what the economist John Maynard Keynes referred to as animal spirits? There are many of us who had their head in their hands when George Osborne embarked on his Broken Britain campaign and capped it off in his first budget by likening Britain to Greece. David Cameron did it again in his recent Tory conference speech. Vote Labour and you'll be voting for Greek-style bankruptcy, was Cameron's message.

webTitle: Bank of England holds interest rates and quantitative easing

fields.standfirst: Governor Mark Carney believes much of the current 2.7% inflation rate can be blamed on one-off shocks
fields.body:
The Bank of England has rejected calls for a rise in interest rates despite a strong run of surveys showing the economy is recovering at its fastest pace since 2010.

In a widely expected decision, the central bank's interest rate setters kept the base rate at 0.5% and the level of its monetary stimulus to the economy, known as quantitative easing, at £375bn.

Some analysts have called for a rise in interest rates in response to the improving economic picture and a recent jump in housing market activity.

However, the bank's monetary policy committee has agreed to maintain its current policy stance until the unemployment rate falls to 7%. It expects to reach this milestone in 2016 after 750,000 jobs have been created.

Governor Mark Carney believes the economy remains weak and much of the current 2.7% inflation rate can be blamed on one-off shocks.

The bank is known to be extremely concerned at the level of business investment, which has continued to fall this year despite the pace of recovery picking up since the spring and many commentators describing it as a well-advanced and sustainable expansion of economic activity. Without a return to healthy rates of business investment, senior Bank staff fear the economy will be forced to rely on consumer spending to maintain growth.

Philip Shaw, UK economist at Investec, said the positive momentum of the economy made more QE unlikely.

"The key question surrounds the possible timing of the first interest rate hike. This is some way off and the likelihood is that the UK faces a long period of steady policy. Nonetheless markets and ourselves are sceptical that this move will occur as far in the future as the second half of 2016, as the Bank of England's guidance implies," he said, adding that the debt markets expect a rise in early 2015.

Peter Dixon, UK economist at Commerzbank, said: "As far as the immediate future is concerned, the BoE is expected to remain on the sidelines.

"Although the economy can be expected to lose momentum relative to recent trends, we look for a self-sustaining recovery with GDP growth in the region of 2% next year. This is not an environment in which additional policy activism is required, implying no more QE as well as no rate moves."

Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The already limited likelihood of any further QE appears to have waned further as the good news on the UK economy has been largely sustained – notwithstanding a few blips such as the surprise marked drop in industrial production in August. Meanwhile, any change in interest rates is clearly a long way off whether or not unemployment ends up falling more rapidly than the Bank of England currently expects."

webTitle: Imagination Technologies climbs as broker downplays competition fears

fields.standfirst: Shares recover after being hit by worries company would lose out at key customers
fields.body:
Chip designer Imagination Technologies has been under the cosh recently.

Its shares have fallen around 16% in a week, partly due to investors shunning the technology sector but also thanks to worries about it using market share at key customers like Apple and MediaTek. But analysts at Morgan Stanley believe the concerns are exaggerated, and an upbeat note from the bank has helped lift Imagination's shares 20.7p or nearly 8% to 282.8p. The bank said:

We believe the fall is overdone as Imagination's graphics processing unit (GPU) is in the latest Apple iPhone products and it continues to see design wins at MediaTek.
Apple hiring at least a dozen former AMD GPU employees has led to worries Apple is developing its own GPU technology, instead of using Imagination's. This is not a new rumour and started back in May 2013. Apple currently has an entire team of engineers that designs its CPU chips, however it still uses Arm's processor architecture. We believe the hiring of GPU engineers indicates Apple will do the same for the development of the GPU, and Apple will continue to use Imagination's architecture. Management reiterated to us they have a strong and very long relationship with Apple and are comfortable that Apple's graphics efforts are based on Imagination's technology.

Recently Arm unveiled a licensing deal with MediaTek relating to its Cortex-A50 cores and the next generation of Mali. This lead to fears Imagination would lose out, but Morgan Stanley said:

MediaTek signed a multi-year license agreement for the PowerVR Series6 'Rogue' technology days in September and Imagination could be in the Octo-core MT6599 chipset for LTE smartphones, indicating the market may be overestimating market share loss at MediaTek.
On 24 times PE, we remain overweight on the stock given the new iPhone 5S uses Rogue, MediaTek license extension and Imagination's exposure to Broadcom all indicating Imagination is well positioned to grow royalty revenues going forward.

webTitle: Inmarsat falls after sell note on satellite group

fields.standfirst: Societe Generale warns of slowdown, dividend pressures and increased competition
fields.body:
Inmarsat, the satellite communications group, has come down to earth after a downbeat broker note.

Shares in the company, which provides services to shipping, aircraft and remote locations, are down 9.5p at 695.5p, more than 1% lower, after Societe Generale began coverage with a sell note and 670p target. It said:

Existing services prospects are slowing, dividend growth looks uncovered, and new services will likely face stiffer competitive pressure.
Price rises in maritime services lifted growth in the first half of 2013, but this benefit is likely now in run-off. US budget sequestration remains a threat to sales and, although lessening, US withdrawals from Afghanistan still pose some headwind. Sales and earnings growth in 2014 looks set to remain slow, despite impressive cost controls, in the face of sharply higher non-cash depreciation and finance costs. Net debt is expected to rise through 2015. So despite strong operating cash flow, dividend growth looks set to be modest and not fully covered by earnings. Inmarsat looks to new Global Xpress [superfast broadband] services from 2015 to restore growth, with 25%-30% of targeted GX sales through 2019 booked or already on Inmarsat systems. However, we expect GX is likely to see tougher competition than Inmarsat's current business, potentially eroding some of the benefits of lower service costs. GX could also cannibalise existing services, reducing the growth stimulus.

Elsewhere security group G4S is down 1.9p at 237.1p after news that South African authorities are taking over the running of a prison the company had been managing.

But Whitbread has added 107p to £30.99 after Oriel Securities moved from hold to buy:

Premier Inn and Costa have strong market positions and significant growth prospects based on the opening of new units - shares have shown some recent weakness and with the prospective PE falling to 16 times for 2014/15, we consider the shares are attractive.

Persimmon has put on another 47p to £11.47 in the wake of the UK government's launch of the next stage of its Help to Buy scheme, and a positive note on Wednesday from Goldman Sachs. Deutsche Bank has added to the upbeat mood by also issuing optimistic comments on the sector:

While we recognise the complexity of the investment case for housebuilders may have increased as macro factors have grown in importance, we believe consensus estimates and stock valuations are yet to reflect the scale of the upside potential to profitability and returns that house price inflation brings.
